creator: Tiny9
title: Tinee9: Resistors in Series
description: This project demonstrates the behavior of resistors in a series circuit, explaining Ohm's Law and how to calculate voltage and current in such a configuration. It includes mathematical examples and a real-life test using an Nscope to verify the calculations.
steps: Understand the basics of resistors and Ohm's Law (V=IR), including voltage, current, and resistance.
Use LTSpice to model a series circuit with a voltage source and two resistors.
Calculate the total resistance in the series circuit by adding the individual resistances.
Calculate the current flowing through the circuit using Ohm's Law (I = V/R).
Calculate the voltage drop across each resistor using Ohm's Law (V = I*R).
Verify that the sum of the voltage drops across the resistors equals the voltage source.
Set up a real-life series circuit using an Nscope, two resistors, and a voltage source.
Connect one end of a resistor to a Channel 1 slot and the other end to the +5V rail slot on the Nscope.
Connect the other resistor from another Channel 1 slot to the GND rail slot.
Measure the voltage at the probe point (between the two resistors) using the Nscope and compare to the calculated value.
Remove the resistor connected to the GND rail and observe the voltage change on the Nscope.
Experiment with different resistor values and recalculate/remeasure the voltage at the probe point. Make sure that your current does not exceed 0.1 Amps = 100 mAmps = 100,000 uAmps.
